title: 109_hr3959
content: The "Corporate Patriot Enforcement Act of 2005" prevents corporate expatriation to avoid US income tax. The definition of "domestic" for corporations and partnerships under the Internal Revenue Code is clarified. In a corporate expatriation transaction, the acquiring corporation is treated as a domestic corporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, a nominally foreign corporation acquires substantially all properties of a domestic corporation, making the acquiring corporation treated as a domestic corporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, if more than 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation, the acquiring corporation is treated as a domestic corporation. In certain cases, the stock ownership requirement can be lowered to 50 percent for a nominally foreign corporation with limited business activities. In a corporate expatriation transaction, a nominally foreign corporation with limited business activities can be treated as a domestic corporation if more than 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, the acquiring corporation must hold more than 80 percent of the stock by vote or value, which is held by former partners of the domestic partnership or related foreign partnerships. In a corporate expatriation transaction, the acquiring corporation must hold more than 80 percent of the stock by vote or value, which is held by former partners of the domestic partnership or related foreign partnerships. Special rules apply, treating a series of related transactions as one transaction and considering stock held by members of the expanded affiliated group including the acquiring corporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, the acquiring corporation must hold more than 80 percent of the stock by vote or value, which is held by former partners of the domestic partnership or related foreign partnerships. Special rules apply, treating a series of related transactions as one transaction and considering stock held by members of the expanded affiliated group including the acquiring corporation. The term 'nominally foreign corporation' refers to any corporation that would be treated as a foreign corporation. The term 'expanded affiliated group' means an affiliated group without regard to ownership. The amendment in section 1504(a) applies to corporate expatriation transactions completed after September 11, 2001, and also to transactions completed on or before that date with respect to taxable matters. The amendment in section 1504(a) applies to corporate expatriation transactions completed after September 11, 2001, and also to transactions completed on or before that date, but only with respect to taxable years of the acquiring corporation beginning after December 31, 2005.
